fighter.description: Fighters are experts in the arts of combat and war. In the Auran Empire, fighters might have learned their arts as legionaries or cataphracts in the Imperial Army, gladiators battling for glory in the arena, raiders off the Jutland coast, or sell-swords in the games of the noble houses.

combatCharacteristics.combatProficiencies: Fighters have weapon proficiency with all weapons, armor proficiency with all armor, and fighting style proficiency with all three optional styles (i.e. the dual weapon, two-handed weapon, and weapon and shield styles).
combatCharacteristics.combatProgression: Fighters advance in attack throws and saving throws by two points every three levels of experience. They increase their base damage roll from successful missile and melee attacks by +1 at 1st level, and by an additional +1 at 3rd, 6th, 9th, and 12th level. They can cleave after killing a foe a maximum of once per round per class level.

abilities.Combat Proficiency: Select one class proficiency from the fighter's proficiency list.

abilities.Starting Equipment: A fighter starts with a short bow and a morning star.

abilities.Combat Progression: Fighters advance in attack throws and saving throws.

startingClassPowers.Manual of Arms: The fighter is highly experienced in military discipline, physical fitness, and weapon drill. He can identify the battle standards and rank insignia of his homeland.

additionalClassPowers.Battlefield Prowess: The fighter’s presence inspires troops he leads. Henchmen and mercenaries gain a +1 bonus to their morale score when personally led by the fighter.

additionalClassPowers.Castle: Acquire a castle worth at least 15,000gp to attract followers. 5d6 × 10 0th level troops will serve him.

explorer.description: Explorers are scouts, settlers, and surveyors hardened to the challenges of the wild. Few adventuring parties would dare the wilderness without an experienced explorer to guide them. Within the Auran Empire, an explorer might be an Imperial scout from the Legions, a barbarian hunter from the northern forests of Jutland, or a settler pushing past the borders of the Empire.

combatCharacteristics.combatProficiencies: Explorers have weapon proficiency with all missile weapons and with all tiny, small, and medium melee weapons. They have armor proficiency with medium, light, and very light armor.
combatCharacteristics.combatProgression: Like fighters, explorers advance in attack throws and saving throws by two points every three levels of experience.

abilities.Combat Proficiency: Select one class proficiency from the explorer's proficiency list.

abilities.Starting Equipment: An explorer starts with a short bow and an old spear.

abilities.Combat Progression: Explorers advance in attack throws and saving throws.

startingClassPowers.Alertness: Explorers gain a +1 bonus to avoid surprise. When using Adventuring proficiency to search or listen, he succeeds on a proficiency throw of 14+.

startingClassPowers.Ambushing: Explorers can ambush any vulnerable opponent, getting a +4 bonus on attack throws and dealing an extra die of damage.

startingClassPowers.Animal Reflexes: Explorers gain a +1 bonus to initiative and avoid surprise.

mage.description: Sometimes called wizards, sorcerers, or magicians, mages study arcane secrets and cast spells. While early in their career mages have only limited power, experienced mages are able to cast a great number of powerful spells. In the Auran Empire, a mage might be a wizard steeped in the lore of the Tower of Knowledge, a sinister sorcerer of Kemesh or the Sunset Kingdoms, or a hedge wizard with strange charms and hodge-podge traditions.

combatCharacteristics.combatProficiencies: Mages have weapon proficiency with clubs, daggers, darts, and staffs. They have no armor proficiency. They have fighting style proficiency with the two-handed weapon style (allowing them to use a staff with both hands).
combatCharacteristics.combatProgression: Mages advance in attack throws and saving throws by only two points every six levels of experience. They do not gain any bonus to damage as they advance in level. They cannot cleave, regardless of their level.

abilities.Arcane Magic: Mages can learn and cast powerful arcane spells.

abilities.Starting Equipment: A mage starts with basic supplies for spellcasting.

abilities.Spell Progression: Mages gain additional spells and levels of spells they can cast.

startingClassPowers.Arcane Magic: Mages can learn and cast powerful arcane spells limited to their repertoire.

startingClassPowers.Collegiate Wizardry: Mages can identify arcane symbols, spell signatures, and trappings of their own order or other orders.

thief.description: Where other classes rely on their valor in battle or power with magic, thieves rely on cunning, stealth, and subterfuge. Sometimes a thief will belong to an organized criminal syndicate from the character’s local town, where he can seek shelter and information between adventures. However, many adventuring thieves are independent of any guild, and some even refuse to call themselves thieves at all — preferring terms such as expert treasure hunter, gentleman adventurer, or dungeoneer. In the Auran Empire, thieves are everywhere, from the slums of the ports of Kushtu to the highest halls of the Senate in Aura.

combatCharacteristics.combatProficiencies: Thieves have weapon proficiency with all missile weapons and with all tiny, small, and medium melee weapons. They have armor proficiency with light and very light armor. They have fighting style proficiency with the dual weapon and two-handed weapon styles, but not with the weapon and shield style.
combatCharacteristics.combatProgression: Thieves advance in attack throws and saving throws by two points every four levels of experience. They do not gain any bonus to damage as they advance in level. They can cleave after killing a foe a maximum of once per round per every two class levels (rounded down).

startingClassPowers.Backstabbing: Thieves can treacherously attack vulnerable opponents, gaining a +4 bonus to hit and additional die of damage.

startingClassPowers.Climbing: Thieves can scale surfaces with the possibility of falling but can move at different speeds during climbing.

startingClassPowers.Hiding: Thieves can become hidden in dim light or darkness with a proficiency throw.

startingClassPowers.Listening: Thieves can listen for sounds and detect noises near doors or passageways.

startingClassPowers.Lockpicking: Thieves can pick mechanical locks, either hastily or methodically.

startingClassPowers.Pickpocketing: Thieves can steal from individuals without them noticing if they succeed in a proficiency throw.

startingClassPowers.Searching: Thieves can find hidden traps, concealed doors, and other hidden features through searching.

startingClassPowers.Shadowy Senses: Thieves have enhanced perception in dim light and can scout effectively without being detected.

startingClassPowers.Sneaking: Thieves can prowl stealthily without being heard or seen if they remain cautious.

startingClassPowers.Streetwise: Thieves can navigate and identify criminal organizations and their signs and symbols.

startingClassPowers.Trapbreaking: Thieves can disarm traps safely using their tools, with various success rates based on their method.

additionalClassPowers.Deciphering: Thieves gain the ability to decipher text such as ciphers and treasure maps.

additionalClassPowers.Hideout: Acquire a hideout to attract followers, with others to assist in criminal endeavors.

additionalClassPowers.Scrollreading: Thieves can read and cast spells from scrolls with proper deciphering and throws.

venturer.description: Commerce is the great wheel upon which the world turns. From the fleshy fingers of slave traders to jewel-clad guild masters, the coin and commodities of the empire are controlled by merchants. But if the stereotypical merchant is a pot-bellied financier profiting from the work of others, the venturer is his opposite: An adventurous world traveler, he personally leads caravans into unknown lands, seeking out exotic goods and new markets. Every venturer is, by definition, an adventurer, and interested in any expedition that promises riches and reward.

combatCharacteristics.combatProficiencies: Venturers have weapon proficiency with arbalests, composite bows, crossbows, daggers, long bows, short bows, and short swords. They have armor proficiency with medium, light, and very light armor. They have fighting style proficiency with the weapon and shield style, but not with the two-handed weapon or dual weapon styles.
combatCharacteristics.combatProgression: Venturers advance in attack throws and saving throws by two points every four levels of experience. They do not gain any bonus to damage as they advance in level. They can cleave after killing a foe a maximum of once per round per every two class levels (rounded down).

abilities.Starting Proficiency: Select one class proficiency from the venturer proficiency list.

abilities.Starting Equipment: Venturers start with a slightly notched short sword, dagger, leather armor, and basic supplies.

startingClassPowers.Bribery: A venturer receives a +1 bonus to reaction rolls if he offers one day’s pay for the target; a +2 bonus for a week’s pay; and a +3 bonus for a month’s pay.

startingClassPowers.Diplomacy: Venturers receive a +1 bonus on all reaction rolls when they attempt to parley with intelligent creatures.

startingClassPowers.Expert Bargaining: Venturers can get the best deals available for goods, services, and information, costing 10% less for purchases and selling for 10% more.

additionalClassPowers.Steady Trade Route: Establishes a steady trade route for transactions in any two types of merchandise between visited markets.

additionalClassPowers.Rumormongering: Venturers can automatically learn 1d4 interesting rumors from old contacts and commercial associates.

assassin.description: Assassins are humans who train to kill by ambush and treachery. Assassins might be back-alley brawlers, violent thugs, or members of an organized guild. Within the Auran Empire, some assassins are members of the Order of the Eclipse, a religious brotherhood of trained killers, but others are simply murders-for-hire or rogues with a taste for violence.

combatCharacteristics.combatProficiencies: Assassins have weapon proficiency with all weapons. They have armor proficiency with medium, light, and very light armor. They have fighting style proficiency with all three optional styles (i.e. the dual weapon, two-handed weapon, and weapon and shield styles).
combatCharacteristics.combatProgression: Assassins advance in attack throws and saving throws as fighters, by two points every three levels of experience. Assassins increase their base damage roll from successful missile and melee attacks by +1 at 1st level and by an additional +1 at 3rd, 6th, 9th, and 12th level. They can cleave after killing a foe a maximum of once per round per class level.

abilities.Backstab: An assassin can backstab any vulnerable opponent, gaining a +4 bonus to hit and extra damage.

abilities.Starting Equipment: Assassins start with a hand axe, dagger, leather armor, and basic supplies.

abilities.Hiding: Assassins can begin hiding in cover, dim light, or darkness and gain benefits based on proficiency throws.

abilities.Sneaking: Assassins can begin sneaking and gain bonuses to surprise rolls against opponents.

abilities.Shadowy Senses: Assassins can see in dim light and scout through dark areas without penalty.

abilities.Streetwise: Assassins learn about criminal organizations and can identify symbols and language.

startingClassPowers.Backstabbing: Assassins are skilled at treacherously attacking unprepared enemies, gaining critical hit advantages.

startingClassPowers.Hiding: Assassins can hide in cover, dim light, or darkness to avoid detection.

startingClassPowers.Sneaking: Assassins can prowl stealthily without making noise and evade detection.

additionalClassPowers.Hideout: Acquire a hideout worth at least 5,000gp to attract followers and start a criminal syndicate.

barbarian.description: Barbarians are tough, hardy warriors from cultures outside of the civilized world. Some barbarians live on the edge of true savagery, while others hail from rich cultures with epic poetry and weapons of steel, but all share an outlander’s mix of contempt and awe for the grand tapestry of civilization. In the Auran Empire, barbarians might be reavers from the bleak wastes of northern Jutland, fierce horse archers from Skysostan, or tribesmen from the Ivory Kingdom jungles of Keita, Munde, and Kushtu.

combatCharacteristics.combatProficiencies: Barbarians are limited to a range of weapon, armor, and fighting style proficiencies that are traditional to their people.
combatCharacteristics.combatProgression: Barbarians advance in attack throws and saving throws by two points every three levels of experience. They increase their base damage roll from their choice of either missile or melee attacks by +1 at 1st level and by an additional +1 at 3rd, 6th, 9th, and 12th level. They can cleave after killing a foe a maximum of once per round per class level.

startingClassPowers.Animal Reflexes: A barbarian gains a +1 bonus to initiative and a +1 bonus to avoid surprise.

additionalClassPowers.Animal Magnetism: Henchmen and mercenaries gain a +1 bonus to their morale score whenever the barbarian personally leads them.

additionalClassPowers.Chieftain’s Hall: Acquire a chieftain’s hall worth at least 15,000gp to attract followers to his service.

bard.description: Successful adventurers live forever in the sagas and songs about their deeds. Remembering and recounting these sagas is the profession of bards. Most bards are content to recite the deeds of others, but some bold few participate in the dangers themselves and become inspiring heroes in their own right. In the Auran Empire, such a bard might be an adventuring minstrel with a sword in his hand and a song at his lips, a warrior-skald of the Jutland kingdoms, or a haughty Kemeshi aristocrat.

combatCharacteristics.combatProficiencies: Bards have weapon proficiency with all missile weapons and with all tiny, small, and medium melee weapons. They have armor proficiency with medium, light, and very light armor. They have fighting style proficiency with all three optional styles (i.e. the dual weapon, two-handed weapon, and weapon and shield styles).
combatCharacteristics.combatProgression: Bards advance in attack throws and saving throws by two points every three levels of experience. They increase their base damage roll from successful missile and melee attacks by +1 at 1st level, and by an additional +1 at 3rd, 6th, 9th, and 12th level. They can cleave after killing a foe a maximum of once per round per class level.

startingClassPowers.Arcane Dabbling: Bards can attempt to use wands, staffs, and other magic items only usable by arcane casters, rolling to succeed.

startingClassPowers.Inspire Courage: Bards can improve the effectiveness of their allies, granting bonuses to attack throws, AC, morale rolls, and saving throws against fear.

startingClassPowers.Jack of All Trades: Bards can learn a class proficiency from any class except for a few specified powers.

startingClassPowers.Listening: Bards can hear noises in caves, hallways, and other locations with a proficiency throw.

startingClassPowers.Loremastery: Bards can decipher runes and identify artifacts with proficiency throws.

startingClassPowers.Multilingual: Bards gain three bonus languages due to their travels.

startingClassPowers.Performance: Bards can work as entertainers, earning income from their performances.

additionalClassPowers.Jack of All Trades II: Bards can learn another class proficiency from any class.

additionalClassPowers.Deciphering: Bards can decipher texts, requiring proficiency throws to succeed.

additionalClassPowers.Chronicles of Battle: Any hirelings gain a +1 bonus to their morale when the bard is present.

additionalClassPowers.Jack of All Trades III: Bards can learn another class proficiency from any class.

additionalClassPowers.Inspire Hope: Bards can grant temporary hit points to allies through inspiring speeches.

additionalClassPowers.Jack of All Trades IV: Bards can learn another class proficiency from any class.

additionalClassPowers.Great Hall: Acquire a great hall to attract followers.

additionalClassPowers.Scrollreading: Bards can read and cast spells from scrolls with proficiency throws.

additionalClassPowers.Jack of All Trades V: Bards can learn another class proficiency from any class.

bladedancer.description: Bladedancers are human women who have dedicated themselves to the service of a goddess of war. They belong to military clerical orders, where they are trained in fighting and casting spells. Within the Auran Empire, most bladedancers are trained to the art from a young age in the Temples of Ianna, Goddess of Love and War. A fully trained bladedancer is highly coveted as a bodyguard and escort by the great noble houses.

combatCharacteristics.combatProficiencies: Bladedancers have weapon proficiency with all swords (including daggers, short swords, swords, and two-handed swords) and all spears (including lances, javelins, polearms, and spears). They have armor proficiency with light and very light armor. They have fighting style proficiency with the dual weapon and two-handed weapon styles, but not with the weapon and shield style.
combatCharacteristics.combatProgression: At first level, bladedancers hit an unarmored foe (AC 0) with an attack throw of 10+. They advance like crusaders in attack throws and saving throws, by two points every four levels of experience. They do not gain any bonus to damage as they advance in level. They can cleave after killing a foe a maximum of once per round per every two class levels (rounded down).

startingClassPowers.Graceful Fighting: The bladedancer gains a +1 bonus to initiative and AC while wearing light or very light armor and carrying minimal encumbrance.

startingClassPowers.Divine Magic: Bladedancers can cast spells granted through prayer and worship, with spell progression based on their level.

startingClassPowers.Strength of Faith: The bladedancer can apply her WIL modifier instead of her STR modifier on any damage roll affected by STR.

startingClassPowers.Theology: Bladedancers can identify religious symbols and know their own faith, acquiring congregants through proselytizing.

startingClassPowers.Weapon Finesse: Bladedancers can apply their DEX modifier instead of STR on melee attack rolls when using proficient weapons.

additionalClassPowers.Minor Magical Research: The bladedancer can scribe scrolls and brew potions.

additionalClassPowers.Major Magical Research: The bladedancer can create permanent magic items such as enchanted armor, rings, or weapons.

additionalClassPowers.Temple: Acquire a temple worth at least 15,000gp to attract devoted followers.

additionalClassPowers.Supreme Magical Research: The bladedancer can learn and cast high-level spells and create magical constructs.

paladin.description: Paladins are champions of Law who fight unceasingly against those who seek to extinguish the light of civilization. Wherever the forces of Chaos marshal to threaten man, paladins can be found, battling back the darkness with courage and steel. Paladins in the Auran Empire are, like crusaders, members of holy militant orders. Unlike the crusaders’ orders, which are dedicated to the service of particular Empyrean deities, the paladins’ orders are dedicated to the deified emperors, heroes, and prophets of Aura. The largest such order is the Knights of the Winged Sun, who hold as their patron the exalted hero-king Valerian Bellësareus.

combatCharacteristics.combatProficiencies: Paladins have weapon proficiency with all swords (including daggers, short swords, swords, and two-handed swords) and all spears (including lances, javelins, polearms, and spears). They have armor proficiency with all armor. They have fighting style proficiency with all fighting styles.
combatCharacteristics.combatProgression: Paladins advance in attack throws and saving throws by two points every three levels of experience. They increase their base damage roll from successful melee attacks (but not missile attacks) by +1 at 1st level, and by an additional +1 at 3rd, 6th, 9th, and 12th level. They can cleave after killing a foe a maximum of once per round per class level.

startingClassPowers.Aura of Protection: Paladins gain a +1 bonus to AC and saving throws against attacks made or effects created by evil creatures.

startingClassPowers.Lay on Hands: Paladins can heal injuries by restoring hit points or curing paralysis.

startingClassPowers.Manual of Arms: Paladins can identify military standards, equipment, and tactics from their homeland.

startingClassPowers.Sanctified Body: Paladins are completely immune to diseases, including magical ones.

startingClassPowers.Sense Evil: Paladins can detect evil creatures and magical items with a sinister red glow.

additionalClassPowers.Holy Fervor: Followers gain a +1 bonus to their morale score when led by the paladin.

additionalClassPowers.Fortress: Acquire a fortress worth at least 15,000gp to attract followers.

priestess.description: Priestesses are human women that have dedicated themselves to the service of a goddess. Unlike crusaders, who are trained in fighting, priestesses belong to non-military orders, and dedicate themselves to spellcasting, ministry, and prayer. Within the Auran Empire, priestesses belong to the Sisters of Mourning (Calefa), Keepers of the Hearth (Mityara), or Temple of the Veil (Ianna). Most priestesses do not become adventurers, but every year a few women are sent forth from their temples into the world at the instructions of the matriarchs.

combatCharacteristics.combatProficiencies: Priestesses have weapon proficiency with clubs, daggers, darts, and staffs. They have no proficiency with armor. They have fighting style proficiency with the two-handed weapon style (allowing them to use a staff with both hands), but not with the dual weapon or weapon and shield styles.
combatCharacteristics.combatProgression: Priestesses advance in attack throws only two points every six levels of experience, but they advance in saving throws by two points every four levels of experience. They do not gain any bonus to damage as they advance in level. They cannot cleave, regardless of their level.

startingClassPowers.Consolation: The priestess can console others, doubling their natural healing for one day.

startingClassPowers.Diplomacy: The priestess receives a +1 bonus on all reaction rolls when parleying with intelligent creatures.

startingClassPowers.Divine Magic: Priestesses can manifest their goddess’s power as divine spells.

startingClassPowers.Lay on Hands: The priestess can heal injuries using her divine magic.

startingClassPowers.Purity of the Body: The priestess is immune to all forms of disease.

startingClassPowers.Theology: Gains proficiency in recognizing religious symbols and teachings.

additionalClassPowers.Minor Magical Research: The priestess can scribe scrolls and brew potions.

additionalClassPowers.Cloister: Acquire a cloister worth at least 15,000gp to attract followers.

additionalClassPowers.Major Magical Research: The priestess can create more powerful magical items.

additionalClassPowers.Supreme Magical Research: The priestess can learn and cast high-level ritual spells.

shaman.description: Shamans are the spiritual guides of tribal peoples. A shaman is responsible for the sacred needs of his tribe, mediating with the tribe’s ancestral spirits and totem animals, and conducting the tribe’s religious rituals. Through his relationship with sacred powers such as gods, powerful ancestors, and animal spirits, the shaman can heal the sick and afflicted, divine wise courses of action, and smite the enemies of his tribe. In the Auran Empire, members of the class might be druids of Rorn, rune-casters of Jutland, medicine men of the Skysos horse peoples, or witch doctors of the Ivory Kingdoms. While most shamans spend their entire lives with their tribe, some shamans are called to adventure by dreams and visions; others adventure out of a desire to learn secrets unavailable in their homelands.

combatCharacteristics.combatProficiencies: Shamans have weapon proficiency with daggers, hand axes, short swords, sling-staffs, staffs, and spears. They have armor proficiency with light and very light armor. They have fighting style proficiency with the weapon and shield and two-handed weapon styles, but not with the dual weapon style.
combatCharacteristics.combatProgression: Shamans advance in attack throws and saving throws by two points every four levels of experience. They do not gain any bonus to damage as they advance in level. They can cleave after killing a foe a maximum of once per round per every two class levels (rounded down).

startingClassPowers.Commune with Spirits: The shaman can commune with ancestral or natural spirits once per week, asking three yes-or-no questions.

startingClassPowers.Divine Magic: Shamans can manifest the power of their tribal gods and spirits through divine spells.

startingClassPowers.Tribal Traditions: Gains expertise in the rites and traditions of his tribe, allowing identification of religious symbols and practices.

startingClassPowers.Totem Animal: Each shaman has a totem animal that provides a bonus proficiency related to its type, and represents the shaman’s bond with nature.

additionalClassPowers.Minor Magical Research: The shaman can scribe magical scrolls and brew potions.

additionalClassPowers.Shapechanging: The shaman can shapechange into their totem animal, gaining its physical characteristics and abilities.

additionalClassPowers.Spiritwalking: Allows for the shaman’s spirit to walk free, assuming the shape of a totem animal or human.

additionalClassPowers.Cloister: Acquire a cloister worth at least 15,000gp to attract followers and begin to expand the reach of the shaman’s order.

additionalClassPowers.Major Magical Research: The shaman can create more powerful magical items like enchanted armor or weapons.

additionalClassPowers.Supreme Magical Research: The shaman can learn to craft high-level ritual spells and magic constructs.

warlock.description: While mages are sometimes colloquially referred to as warlocks, the true warlock is a far more sinister individual. A warlock is one who seeks alliance with dark beings and pursues forbidden lore, hoping to find a quicker, easier path to power than the methodical practices of magecraft. Many warlocks become adventurers to plumb the secrets of dusty tombs, forgotten crypts, and hidden sanctums. Few do so for heroic motives. These practices leave warlocks reviled and condemned in the Auran Empire. The Tower of Knowledge bars known warlocks from its august halls entirely. Warlocks are treated with respect and more than a little fear in the Sunset Kingdoms of Kemesh, Somirea, and Celdorea, and many assume positions of power in those societies.

startingClassPowers.name: Arcane Magic
startingClassPowers.description: Warlocks can learn and cast powerful arcane spells. The number and levels of spells the warlock can cast in a single day are listed on the Warlock Spell Progression table. A warlock’s spell selection is limited to the spells in his repertoire. A warlock’s repertoire can include the number of spells up to the number and level of spells listed for his level, increased by his Intellect bonus.

startingClassPowers.name: Occultism
startingClassPowers.description: Every warlock has studied the forbidden secrets of the occult. On a proficiency throw of 11+, he can name the popular titles and symbols of chthonic powers; identify the type of undead creature encountered; and otherwise recall information of interest to demonology and necromancy. (This class power counts as one rank of Knowledge (Occult) proficiency.)

darkPaths.name: Demonology
darkPaths.description: Diabolists who call on the demonic power of the Outer Darkness.

darkPaths.name: Necromancy
darkPaths.description: Morbid practitioners of the forbidden craft of necromancy.

darkPaths.name: Transmogrification
darkPaths.description: Sculptors of flesh who create living horrors.

additionalClassPowers.name: Dark Path II
additionalClassPowers.description: The warlock’s dark path grants him his second reward.

additionalClassPowers.name: Dark Path III
additionalClassPowers.description: The warlock’s dark path grants him his third reward.

additionalClassPowers.name: Minor Magical Research
additionalClassPowers.description: The warlock can research spells, scribe magical scrolls, and brew potions.

additionalClassPowers.name: Dark Path IV
additionalClassPowers.description: The warlock’s dark path grants him his fourth reward.

additionalClassPowers.name: Dark Path V
additionalClassPowers.description: The warlock’s dark path grants him his fifth reward.

additionalClassPowers.name: Major Magical Research
additionalClassPowers.description: The warlock can create more powerful magic items such as weapons, rings, and staffs.

additionalClassPowers.name: Sanctum
additionalClassPowers.description: By acquiring a sanctum worth at least 15,000gp, the warlock can attract followers to his service.

additionalClassPowers.name: Dark Path VI
additionalClassPowers.description: The warlock’s dark path grants him his sixth reward.

additionalClassPowers.name: Supreme Magical Research
additionalClassPowers.description: The warlock can learn and cast ritual arcane spells of great power (7th, 8th, and 9th level), craft magical constructs, and create magical cross-breeds. If chaotic, the warlock can create necromantic servants and become undead.

corruptingWeaknesses.label: Disfigured
corruptingWeaknesses.description: Each disfigurement imposes a -2 penalty to reaction rolls with sapient creatures of Lawful or Neutral alignment.

corruptingWeaknesses.label: Distrusted
corruptingWeaknesses.description: A reaction roll with sapient creatures of Lawful or Neutral alignment can never achieve a friendly (12+) result.

corruptingWeaknesses.label: Enervated
corruptingWeaknesses.description: The warlock’s Constitution is reduced by 2 points each time this weakness occurs.

corruptingWeaknesses.label: Frightening to Beasts
corruptingWeaknesses.description: The warlock suffers a -4 reaction roll when encountering animals or giant animals. He cannot ride normal mounts.

corruptingWeaknesses.label: Haunted
corruptingWeaknesses.description: Whispers from the beyond plague the warlock, imposing a -2 penalty to listening throws and -1 penalty to initiative and surprise rolls.

corruptingWeaknesses.label: Mad
corruptingWeaknesses.description: Each day the warlock must make a Spells saving throw or go mad for 1-10 hours.

corruptingWeaknesses.label: Mutated
corruptingWeaknesses.description: Roll 1d10 on the Magical Mutations subtable. Each subsequent occurrence increases the roll by 1.

corruptingWeaknesses.label: Nocturnal
corruptingWeaknesses.description: The warlock cannot regain spells unless he sleeps during the day. He suffers a penalty of -2 to all throws when in sunlight.

corruptingWeaknesses.label: Obsessed
corruptingWeaknesses.description: The warlock’s Will is reduced by 2 points each time this weakness occurs.

corruptingWeaknesses.label: Sleepless
corruptingWeaknesses.description: Each time the warlock attempts to rest, he must roll 1d6. On a 1, he regains no hit points and recovers no spells.

witch.description: The ignorant will often refer to any female spellcaster as a witch. Actual witches, however, are women who practice a distinct craft of magic. Like priestesses and shamans, witches invoke divine magic, but they do not organize into communities of faith nor do they dedicate themselves to the service of their gods or goddesses. Rather, they seek to gain personal knowledge and strength by bartering with the old powers of the world. Through ancient pacts, forgotten prayers, secret names of power, and other means, they appease, bargain, coerce, convince, and harness divine power to their own ends. Their quest for knowledge and power often drives witches to become adventurers.

startingClassPowers.name: Studious Divine Magic
startingClassPowers.description: By reminding the gods of ancient pacts and coercing them with forgotten prayers and binding hymns, witches can cast divine spells. Unlike most other divine casters, who receive their spells from prayer, witches receive their spells from study. Witches follow the same spell progression and use the same rules for learning and casting spells as mages. They record their repertoires of spells in spell books and can learn new spells from scribing scrolls or studying other divine spell books. They select their spells from the divine spell list, rather than the arcane spell list, however, and cannot learn or cast spells found in arcane spell books.

startingClassPowers.name: Tradition
startingClassPowers.description: Every witch belongs to a tradition, which defines her approach to the magic and her relationship with the gods and spirits that are her source of power. The regions within the Auran Empire campaign setting associated with each tradition are noted below. Judges can create other traditions for their own campaign settings where necessary.

startingClassPowers.name: Village Wisdom
startingClassPowers.description: All witches can perform minor acts of 'hedge magic' useful in village life, such as alleviating cold symptoms, easing the pains of childbirth, driving away bedbugs from a mattress, removing mites and ticks from a creature, and so on. Each use takes 1 turn (10 minutes).

traditions.name: Antiquarian Witch
traditions.description: Wise women who focus on healing and beneficial potions, they practice their traditional craft wherever rural human settlements may be found.

traditions.name: Chthonic Witch
traditions.description: Malefic practitioners who consort with the darkest of powers, reveling in the seduction and corruption of the innocent.

traditions.name: Sylvan Witch
traditions.description: Reclusive witches who travel the borderlands between human settlements and fey forests.

rewards.reward: Close Friend of Birds and Beasts

additionalClassPowers.name: Brew Potions
additionalClassPowers.description: The witch can brew potions. However, she cannot yet research new spells or scribe scrolls.

additionalClassPowers.name: Minor Magical Research
additionalClassPowers.description: The witch can research new spells. However, she cannot yet scribe scrolls.

additionalClassPowers.name: Scribe Scrolls
additionalClassPowers.description: The witch can create magic scrolls.

additionalClassPowers.name: Witch’s Cottage
additionalClassPowers.description: By acquiring a cottage worth at least 15,000gp, the witch can attract followers to her service.

additionalClassPowers.name: Major Magical Research
additionalClassPowers.description: The witch can create more powerful magic items such as weapons, rings, and staffs.

additionalClassPowers.name: Supreme Magical Research
additionalClassPowers.description: The witch can learn and cast ritual divine spells of great power (7th, 8th, and 9th level) and craft magical constructs. If chaotic, the witch can create necromantic servants and become undead.

codeOfBehavior.obligation: The witch must light a candle and pray over it for one turn (10 minutes) at noon and midnight.
The witch cannot lie. She can equivocate, prevaricate, speak in riddles, or stay silent, however.
If the witch unjustly wrongs another human or demi-human, she must redress the wrong at threefold its value.
If the witch accepts a gift, she must offer a gift of threefold value to the gift giver.
If the witch suffers a personal wrong, she must exact retribution of threefold value from the one who wronged her.
The witch’s soul is sworn to service after death. She cannot be restored to life by any means short of a wish or miracle.

dwarvenCraftpriest.description: Nothing is so revered among the dwarven people as craftsmanship. A dwarf's work is his life, and the spirits of great dwarven artisans are believed to live on forever in their masterpieces. The veneration of these relics falls to the care of a caste of dwarves known as craftpriests. While most craftpriests attend to the shrines and monuments of their clan, young craftpriests are sometimes sent forth to recover monuments to the glorious past from the ancient ruins and wastelands of the world.

combatProgression.cleave: once per round per every two class levels (rounded down)

startingClassPowers.name: Attention to Detail
startingClassPowers.description: Craftpriests gain a +3 bonus on proficiency throws for any proficiencies they learn.

startingClassPowers.name: Crafting
startingClassPowers.description: Every craftpriest is a master in a particular type of craft, such as armor-making, leatherworking, weapon-smithing, etc. Craftpriests can produce 40gp worth of items per month and supervise 2 journeymen and 4 apprentices in their craft. When examining works of his craft, craftpriests can identify masterwork items, rare materials, and famous artisans with a proficiency throw of 2+ on 1d20.

startingClassPowers.name: Rebuke Undead
startingClassPowers.description: Craftpriests can rebuke undead as crusaders of their class level. In order to rebuke undead, they must be equipped with a holy symbol representing the ancestor or relic they venerate.

startingClassPowers.name: Studious Divine Magic
startingClassPowers.description: By invoking the rites and rituals of their venerable ancestors, craftpriests can cast divine spells. Craftpriests follow the same spell progression and use the same rules for learning and casting spells as mages. They record their repertoires of spells in spell books and can learn new spells from scribing scrolls or studying other divine spell books. They select their spells from the divine spell list, rather than the arcane spell list, however, and cannot learn or cast spells found in arcane spell books.

startingClassPowers.name: Theology
startingClassPowers.description: Craftpriests are trained in the rites and rituals of the dwarven faith and are broadly knowledgeable about other races’ and cultures’ religions. They can acquire congregants through proselytizing. They can automatically identify religious symbols, trappings, and holy days of the dwarven faith, and recognize those of other faiths with a proficiency throw of 8+ on 1d20.

additionalClassPowers.name: Minor Magical Research
additionalClassPowers.description: The craftpriest can research spells, scribe scrolls, and brew potions.

additionalClassPowers.name: Major Magical Research
additionalClassPowers.description: The craftpriest can create permanent magic items, such as weapons, rings, and staffs. He can also craft magical constructs such as golems.

additionalClassPowers.name: Vault
additionalClassPowers.description: By acquiring a vault worth at least 15,000gp, the craftpriest can attract dwarves to his service. 1d4+1 × 10 dwarven mercenaries and 1d6 dwarven craftpriests of 1st – 3rd level arrive to serve him as followers within 1d3 months of him acquiring the vault. If the craftpriest has already acquired a vault, the followers arrive to serve him within 1d3 months of him reaching 9th level.

racialTraits.name: Dwarf Tongues
racialTraits.description: Dwarves can speak the Common and Dwarvish tongues and, because of their frequent interaction underground with beastmen, can also speak Goblin, Gnome, and Kobold.

racialTraits.name: Hardy
racialTraits.description: Dwarves are tough. The target values for all their Blast saving throws are improved by 3, while the target values for all their other saving throws are improved by 4.

racialTraits.name: Sensitivity to Rock and Stone
racialTraits.description: Dwarves gain a +1 bonus to surprise rolls when underground. When using Adventuring proficiency to search or listen, they succeed on a proficiency throw of 14+ (instead of the usual 18+). If separately proficient in Searching they gain a +4 bonus to their throw instead. If separately proficient in Listening, they gain a +2 bonus to their throw instead.

codeOfBehavior: The craftpriest must always display a holy symbol indicating the relic he venerates somewhere on his person when in public.
The craftpriest must sing hymns on high holy days each week. Singing hymns requires one hour of ancillary activity.
The craftpriest must only use the traditional weapons of the dwarves.
If the craftpriest discovers a dwarven relic in the hands of outsiders, he must recover the relic by any means necessary.
The craftpriest must not use his divine magic to harm or hinder fellow dwarves, unless ordered to do so by a superior during a time when his vault is at war with another vault.

dwarvenVaultguard.description: Dwarves trained to defend their race’s underground vault from the endless hordes that threaten it are called vaultguards. Though most vaultguards are born, live and die in the vault, from time to time a young vaultguard will be dispatched to foreign realms on a warrior’s pilgrimage. The few vaultguards who return from such pilgrimages bring gold and glory to their clans, often leading them to found new vaults and become great lords.

combatProficiencies: all weapons except long bows or two-handed swords

combatProgression.cleave: once per round per class level

startingClassPowers.name: Manual of Arms
startingClassPowers.description: The vaultguard is highly experienced in military discipline, physical fitness, and weapon drill. He can automatically identify the battle standards, equipment, great captains, military slang, and rank insignia of his clan and vault. He can identify those of other clans, vaults, or realms with a proficiency throw of 11+.

additionalClassPowers.name: Battlefield Prowess
additionalClassPowers.description: The vaultguard’s presence inspires troops he leads. Any henchmen and mercenaries hired by the vaultguard gain a +1 bonus to their morale score whenever he personally leads them. This bonus stacks with any modifiers from the vaultguard’s Charisma or proficiencies.

additionalClassPowers.name: Vault
additionalClassPowers.description: By acquiring a vault worth at least 15,000gp, the vaultguard can attract dwarves to his service. 3d6 × 10 1st level dwarven mercenaries arrive to serve him as followers within 1d3 months of him acquiring the vault. If the vaultguard already acquired a vault, the followers arrive to serve him within 1d3 months of him reaching 9th level. The vaultguard must pay his followers the ordinary rates for mercenaries and henchmen or they leave his service.

racialTraits.name: Dwarf Tongues
racialTraits.description: Dwarves can speak the Common and Dwarvish tongues and, because of their frequent interaction underground with beastmen, can also speak Goblin, Gnome, and Kobold.

racialTraits.name: Hardy
racialTraits.description: Dwarves are tough. The target values for all their Blast saving throws are improved by 3, while the target values for all their other saving throws are improved by 4.

racialTraits.description: Dwarves gain a +1 bonus to surprise rolls when underground. When using Adventuring proficiency to search or listen, they succeed on a proficiency throw of 14+ (instead of the usual 18+). If separately proficient in Searching they gain a +4 bonus to their throw instead. If separately proficient in Listening, they gain a +2 bonus to their throw instead.

dwarvenVaultguardProficiencyList: Combat Trickery (force back, knock down, overrun, sunder, wrestling)
